text: I was raised on a Catalan and crop farm
in Perry County from the age of one year
old the coal ash spill in Tennessee
occurred back in December we're just
concerned that in order to clean that
situation up in Tennessee the problem is
being shifted down here for us to tend
to when we didn't want it to start with
Perry County is one of the poorest
counties in Alabama unemployment sits at
seventeen percent businesses are
shuttered up and down Main Street and a
third of all households live below the
poverty line so when a holding pond
broke at a Tennessee power plant and
released millions of tons of coal ash
into the environment Perry County
Commissioners made a bid ultimately
successful to dispose of the coal ash at
a local landfill the ash contains
arsenic lead and other heavy metals but
it also brings with it more than three
million dollars in expected fees for the
county as well as some 30 jobs I
Reverend James our murder from six to
eight years old I live less than 500
feet away from the landfill there's a
history of the landfill this they parked
their target poor black uneducated
economic deprived communities I think to
put the landfill in only about to tell
you that your school is alright we just
missed it Commissioner Albert Turner Jr
hosts a local talk radio show he
dismisses any charges of racism the
economic racism would have taken place
hat EPA and TVA had not awarded this
contract to us it would have gone to
another area which may not have been
black which may not have been poor
that's when it would have been economic
racism because you wouldn't want us to
move and pull ourselves up by our
bootstraps my name is Ellis long I'm
from Uniontown originally my family
built the house that we're in
in 1840 I say that there's there's no
amount of money no number of jobs that
that would justify accepting this sort
of refuse and which will affect our our
future our children our children's
children I'm really upset about the fact
people went consulted I'm sunset by
upset about the fact when we knew
anything when all these citizen knew
anything they had they had to set in
motion and they said it's a done deal
Johnny flowers was a county commissioner
for 18 years before being defeated for
supporting the creation of the landfill
he also supports the disposal of coal
ash here in part because of the unique
fix oil under the landfill known as
Selma Chuck he insists that the water
supply is safe this soil here to us is
like the oil is for Texans the Texas or
produces all in this soil year for us in
this part of the community is the best
thing for a landfill as track is always
good for and I believe that God gave
each community what it need to survive
one thing is certain hundreds of box
cars loaded with coal ash are arriving
every week a total of about three
million tons of coal ash will be dumped
in Perry County and county commissioners
are lobbying for even more which would
bring much needed money and jobs but at
a cost too high for many residents
